The ferritin blood test measures the level of ferritin in the blood; this is how ferritin levels can be measured. Ferritin is a protein inside your cells that stores iron, allowing your body to use it. The test can be done on serum, plasma, liver, red blood cells, and other specimens; [5, 7].
Ferritin levels can indicate iron deficiency or iron overload in a person; [1, 3, 7].

Monitoring ferritin levels can also be used as an indicator of iron deficiency or iron overload; it plays an essential role in iron homeostasis and can be used to assess the impact of interventions. [2, 3, 4]
Ferritin is a protein that plays a key role in iron metabolism, with the inherent ability to store and release iron when the body needs it. Body serum level ...; [2, 3, 4]
Ferritin is found in the body as the main iron storage protein. The majority of ferritin is intracellular, but a soluble form can also be found in the blood; [5].

Ferritin plays an essential role in iron metabolism and acts as a buffer against iron deficiency and iron overload. It is the major intracellular iron-storage protein and allows the body to store and release iron when needed. It is also a critical factor in maintaining the balance of iron in the body. [0, 1, 2, 5]
[Iron is essential for hemoglobin synthesis and is indispensable to all cells for the production of heme and iron-sulfur (Fe/S) clusters]; [6, 7].

Iron deficiency, iron overload, insulin sensitivity, Type 2 diabetes, liver disease, cardiovascular disease, high glutamate pyruvate transaminase, obesity, and high fasting blood glucose have been linked to ferritin. [4, 7]

[Ferritin is considered an important protein to understand because it plays essential roles in cellular and systemic iron homeostasis, serves as the major intracellular iron-storage protein, and its levels can be used as an indicator of iron storage. Additionally, ferritin malfunction is associated with impaired iron homeostasis]; [0, 2, 4, 7].
